newsitem.title: GERMANY: ERM II has good chances of success-Lamfalussy.
newsitem.headline: ERM II has good chances of success-Lamfalussy.

text.p: A second ERM joined by nations unable to participate in the planned currency union in 1999 has a good chance to succeed, and is unlikely to trip up at the same places as the original ERM did, Alexandre Lamfalussy, president of the European Monetary Institute said Friday.
He said Europe had learned from the mistakes of the past in designing the so-called ERM II.

"Experience with the existing ERM has been acknowledged in the design of the new ERM II," Lamfalussy said, stressing the "risk of overvalued real exchange rates and their corollary - the subsequent excessive real depreciation of currencies - would be greatly reduced."
In the future "central rates would be a matter of common agreement, thus helping to protect against future misalignments," Lamfalussy told a banking congress.
By giving the new central bank the right and obligation to trigger realignment procedures, Lamfalussy said future realignements would be depoliticised.
"The possibility of preventive realignments, without prior tensions, is of crucial importance," Lamfalussy said.
The EMI is the forerunner to Europe's future central bank.
